Award.AwardTitle: Student-Author Travel Grant for the International Conferences on Biomedical and Health Informatics and on Wearable and Implantable Body Sensor Networks 2019

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is to support doctoral student travel and participation for student travel support and participation in the doctoral mentoring program at the collocated 2019 International Conference on Biomedical and Health Informatics and the annual International Conference on Wearable and Implantable Body Sensor Networks. These collocated conferences provides a supportive scientific forum for students focusing on computing, health informatics and engineering in the area of human health. The International Conference on Biomedical and Health Informatics and International Conference on Wearable and Implantable Body Sensor Networks will provide a forum for expert and peer critique of students' research with the goal of improving their science. Student participants will also have the opportunity to receive networking support and career advice from internationally-recognized experts. Overall, the travel support brings together students with experts who might not otherwise engage with one another and engage in multidisciplinary groups targeting science the area of human health.

This proposal supports doctoral students by providing a doctoral forum focused on encouraging students to learn from peers and experts from multiple perspectives to understand how innovative computing, informatics, engineering and biomedical science combine to make the most impact in the area of human health. In addition, student participation in a roundtable provided at the conference enables students to explore their science and see different career paths for researchers in this area. The International Conference on Biomedical and Health Informatics and International Conference on Wearable and Implantable Body Sensor Networks conference exposes participants to different scientific disciplinary approaches, supports networking with conference attendees and is designed to support the development of the next generation of scholars in this area and create a bridge between the scientific and health disciplines.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award provided support for students to attend the 2019 IEEE International Conferences on Biomedical and Health Informatics (BHI) and on Wearable and Implantable Body Sensor Networks (BSN). These co-located conferences provided the premier opportunity to discuss the growing field of wearable and implantable sensors for human health monitoring and the health informatics and advanced analytics designed to process the data from those and other medical data sources.  Through this travel award we were able to provide support for 20 students (undergraduate, early stage graduate, and finishing graduate students) to attend the conferences, present their work, participate in a PhD research workshop, and network with other peer researchers. Ultimately, award amounts of $500 were made to each participant to cover the cost of registering for the conference, except for two students whose overall spending to participate in the conference was lower than $500 (i.e., $416.66 and $470.00). In total, $9,886.86 was used to support the travel award. This amount was selected to allow for a diverse range of qualified students that applied for the travel award. 20 students from 20 US universities were selected. A three-member committee reviewed all applications, ranking them on their personal statements, research interests, and letter from supervising professor.

 

Intellectual Merit: 20 Students were able to attend and present their work at the 2019 BHI and BSN conferences. Students were also invited to attend a symposium for emerging research topics with faculty to discuss early- and late-stage research topics aiming to identify new, emerging problems. Participants were grouped with similar researchers and a faculty mentor who led them through a discussion during the conference session. This discussion focused on the background and current state of the art of their research problems, a discussion of why the problems are interesting and challenging, and discussion of the contribution of each student’s research to the field. For more senior students, this discussion focused on framing the problem well for highlighting the impact and anticipating the next steps in their careers. For early-stage students, this focused on brainstorming ideas with the students and discuss the right way to approach innovative research questions with them. All students had an opportunity to participate in a special panel session where they could network with established faculty members and leadership of the conference organizers. They also had an opportunity to participate in the student colloquium, in which they share their work with fellow students and researchers, seek collaborative and joint research opportunities, and develop new ideas through interactive discussions. Additionally, this travel award allowed students who were authors of papers at the conference to register and present their work.

 

Broader Impact: Educational and networking opportunities allowed students to engage with faculty in a variety of similar fields across multiple institutions. This allowed students to engage with each other on identifying emerging topics of interest that might lead to future research directions for all involved.
